Hi Tim, 
Thanks for the great question on apps for cities! Here are some resources you may find useful as your explore this with your local government. 
Here is an article from a recent issue of PM Magazine regarding local government app creation. http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9509/public/innovation.cfm?title=Innovation%20Edge&subtitle=&author=
The City of Palo Alto CA Becomes a Model of Transparency http://icma.org/en/Article/103182/Palo_Alto_CA_Becomes_a_Model_of_Transparency
In addition to these resources you might consider hosting a hack-a-thon where you provide residents with data about the community and challenge them to create apps about the city for fun! Many local governments have successfully done this  with great results!
The ICMA and Esri Local Government and Technology Initiative http://icma.org/en/Article/103049/EsriICMA_Local_Government_and_Technology_Initiative
Can Government Create a Following? Leveraging the New GIS App Economy http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/304244/Can_Government_Create_a_Following_Leveraging_the_New_GIS_App_Economy
I hope you find these resources helpful and that you let us know what your local government ends up doing! It is always exciting to see case studies of local government innovation. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

answers.author: Eric Norenberg
answers.text:
The City of Oberlin, in partnership with the Oberlin business community and Oberlin College, developed a mobile app to be the one stop for visitors, residents, college students, etc. to go for information about the City, College, and local businesses.  We have event listings, maps, parking information, local offers by businesses, and of course, city information, including a form to report problems.  Please download our app from Google Play or the App Store and check it out. We worked with www.citizensync.com to build the app.  The total first year cost was about $4,000 (split three ways by the partners).  Annual maintenance will be about $1,000.  The advantage of working with Citizen Sync is the ongoing support ... we just e-mail new events or other updates and they do the rest.

author: Tim Cox
text:
I am interested in finding out if anyone has experience with creating (or hiring a company to create a mobile app). I have found some great resources online but I would like to learn more about how apps are being used in smaller cities. The City of Fairburn, GA has a population of about 14,000. 
What was your experience with this process? What did you like? What did you dislike? What would you do different? What is the cost associated with creation and implementation? Do your residents seem to like this feature?
Any information that you can provide is greatly appreciated. 
Thanks,
title: City App
